prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "reglet and furniture". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Reglet and the Furniture

Under the rafters, forme and chase,
while platen-breezes purr,
the slug-and-space kept slinking pace
with splinter, nick, and burr.

"Keep true your gauge," the elder spoke,
"and square your nimble sight;
for Reglet slips with shimmy stroke,
and Furniture will bite.

"They creep along the galley-skin,
they joggle quire and gutter;
their wiles will skew the margins thin
and make the measure flutter."

He primed his stick, the comper's stave,
and set his chase-key sure;
he prowled the roller's inky cave
for Reglet and Furniture.

In hushling hum the bed did drum,
the tympan smelled of tar;
then reglet-thin a shadow came,
a shimmy-shiver scar.

And bulky blocks with bevel-mouth
went shogging, wide and square—
the Furniture, a grumblish growth,
with faces dull as air.

Snap-clack! the wedges bit and sang;
he locked them trim and true.
He measured out the mischief's wrang
and squeezed the slither through.

He gauged and set and squared and pressed,
till all the forme lay clean;
no boggle-block nor shimmy-pest
could jog the printed scene.

"O letter-light!" the elder cried,
"and merry, merry day!
Come tuck the leads and wash the ride—
you've kept the warp at bay!"

Under the rafters, forme and chase,
while platen-breezes purr,
the slug-and-space keep steady pace
with reglet and furniture.
label: high
judge_raw:

<C5_think>Final stanza repeats content words and phrases from the opening stanza ("Under the rafters," "forme and chase," "slug-and-space," "reglet and furniture") with strong echo effect; ring composition confirmed.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Early admonition present: second stanza has "Keep true your gauge" ... "Furniture will bite" - a cautionary warning to the protagonist.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Preparation shown: protagonist primes stick, sets chase-key, prowls searching before confrontation.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Clear encounter/confrontation: a shadow comes, followed by the description of "Furniture," an adversarial creature outside canonical Jabberwocky terms.</C8_think>
<C9_think>Decisive action: "Snap-clack! ... bite and sang," then he "locked them trim and true," "measured out the mischief's wrang," culminating with cleaning the forme; clear decisive resolution.</C9_think>

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "blued screw in a movement". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Blued Screw in a Movement

In tockish dusk the gearlings glide,
Through brassling dew and sprocket bloom;
The balance-beat from side to side
Breathes fog across the crystal's gloom.

"Hush, hush," crooned old escapement sage,
"Keep steady thumb and tender wit;
A blued screw in a movement—gage
Of coiled tempests—will not quit."

So took I up my driver slim,
My tweezers keen, my oiling pen;
With heart a metronomic hymn,
I turned the caseback once, and then—

Down whirrigo the wheelworks sang,
The jewel-eyes went ruby-bright;
The pallet fork did clickle-clang,
The mainspring hummed a copper light.

There, coiled within the plates, I saw
A spiral cobalt, sly and shrewd—
A blued screw in a movement, raw,
That drank the oil and sipped the mood.

I set my tip in tempered star,
And wound my will to finger-tune;
It squeaked a bite of threadling spar,
My tool sang tinker-taddle-tune.

Clack-crisp! It loosened, spun, and flew;
I set a kinder skysteel there.
Now tickle-time runs true-and-true,
And whirrs a merry, gearsome air.
label: high
judge_raw:

<C1_think>Title line "Blued Screw in a Movement" present and non-empty before first stanza.</C1_think>

Only about half of stanzas clearly rhyme (2,4) or have slant rhyme; also, the rhyme scheme is not AABB dominant. So slightly below 60% stanzas rhyme on 2,4 lines -> no.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Final stanza does not echo first stanza’s phrasing or content words; no clear refrain or ring composition. No repeated phrase or content words linking last to first stanza.</C5_think>

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "murmuration over stubble". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Murmuration Over Stubble

Gloam-tide, and the stubbly leas
did scrindle-wind along the grange;
All whisperwing the barnward eaves,
and starflocks flitterstrange.

Out sloomed the murkle-murmur-mass,
a swarf of fugle-sable sweep,
that swurled in looplings, glass on glass,
and dumbly sang the deep.

Above the stubble’s bristle-tide,
where gleaner-motes like embers lay,
the blacklace cloud went side to side,
all knittle-knot and sway.

A threshling lad with scuffèd boots
stood whistling through his mittened knurl;
The field-ghosts stirred in barley-roots,
and up leapt loop on whirl.

They skreel and skurl, those pattle-wings,
in shiver-sheer and silver din;
They braid the dusk in belling rings,
then dwindle hush and thin.

O murmlit throng! O swalesome spume!
O drift that thinks with ten-thousand eyes!
You sloom the hedge, you cram the gloom,
you stitch the west with sighs.

When hushlet night on stubble spills,
and cinders star the furrowed loam,
the murmur-cloud unknits and stills—
the field takes back its home.
label: low
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title present: The poem has a distinct non-empty title line before the first stanza ("Murmuration Over Stubble").</C1_think>
<C2_think>Quatrain shape: The poem contains 7 stanzas, all quatrains (4 lines each), which is within the required 5-8 stanzas.</C2_think>
<C3_think>Ballad meter echo: Lines do not consistently alternate in length or content word count difference; no clear longer/shorter alternation pattern in majority (>60%) of stanzas.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Ballad rhyme: The end rhymes of lines 2 and 4 in most stanzas are weak or inconsistent; some slant rhyme possible but not clearly ≥60% rhyme with avoidance of AABB dominance.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Ring composition: The final stanza does not echo the first stanza with two or more repeated content words or refrains; no strong ring structure detected.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Warning/admonition: No admonition or cautionary phrase addressing a protagonist early or anywhere.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Preparation/armament: No indication that a protagonist prepares, waits, arms, or readies for a confrontation.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Encounter/confrontation: No clear meeting of protagonist and adversary or obstacle; action is descriptive, atmospheric, no confrontation.</C8_think>
<C9_think>Slaying/decisive action: No decisive violent or turning action resolving a tension.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Return/celebration: No jubilant homecoming or return celebration expressed.</C10_think>
<C11_think>Coinage count: Many distinct neologisms and coinages (e.g., scrindle-wind, whisperwing, murkle-murmur-mass, swarf, looplings, starflocks, pattle-wings, hushlet, murmlit, swalesome); definitely 8+ distinct invented words.</C11_think>
<C12_think>Coinage spread: At least one coinage appears in every stanza (e.g., stubbly, scrindle-wind, murkle-murmur-mass, looplings, threshling, pattle-wings, hushlet).</C12_think>
<C13_think>Creature/entity naming: No non-canonical named creature or central adversary/entity (like non-Jabberwocky monster); mostly nature/phenomena descriptions.</C13_think>
<C14_think>Onomatopoeia: No clear onomatopoeic bursts like “snicker-snack,” “Pop!,” or “Hiss!”; sounds are described but without onomatopoeic words.</C14_think>
<C15_think>Alliteration/consonance: Multiple stanzas show clear alliteration (e.g., “stubbly leas did scrindle-wind,” “blacklace cloud went side to side,” “pattle-wings… shiver-sheer and silver din”); ≥2 stanzas with deliberate alliteration/consonance present.</C15_think>
<C16_think>Arc order: No canonical narrative arc of warning → preparation → encounter → decisive act → return/celebration; poem is atmosphere and nature focused.</C16_think>
<C17_think>No verbatim lines: No lines match canonical poem verbatim; completely original wording.</C17_think>
<C18_think>Canonical budget: Very few or no canonical tokens present; mostly novel vocabulary so canonical tokens ≤8.</C18_think>
<C19_think>Syllable tightness: Longer lines generally about 8–9 syllables and shorter lines 5–7 syllables; meter is fairly consistent though relaxed and imprecise, but mostly within range.</C19_think>
<C20_think>Rhyme variety: Rhyme endings vary considerably; repetition of rhyme words minimal; no exact rhyme endings repeated more than twice.</C20_think>
<C21_think>Lexical repetition guard: No overused content words; vocabulary is diverse without single content word overused highly.</C21_think>
<C22_think>Coinage variety: Coinages do not appear to predominately share single root/suffix; at least 4 distinct roots visible (scrindle, murkle, pattle, hushlet, murmlit, etc.).</C22_think>
<C23_think>Topic adherence: The poem primarily describes natural phenomenon (flocking birds/cloud), no evident connection to "Jabberwocky" style battle or invented creature theme.; topic adherence to Jabberwocky style theme is weak or absent because no creature or confrontation</C23_think>
<C24_think>Subtext: There is an implied motif of natural flocking, transience, and peace fading into night, giving a coherent implied layer beyond surface description.</C24_think>
</think>
